comments:
When focus is restored to a dirty text editor of a file that has been deleted,
the user will be prompted to save or close that editor.  If the choose save and
then attempt to save the file with the same name as it had before, an error log
is generated.

Steps to reproduce:
1) Create a new file (i.e. Simple>File) in the project.
2) Modify the contents of the file so the editor is dirty.
3) Delete the file using the Navigator View.
4) Set Focus to the dirty editor.
5) Click "Save" on the dialog that appears.
6) Attempt to save the file as is with the same file name.

When you click the "OK" button, the following error appears in the Error Log View:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Attempted to beginRule:
P/org.eclipse.examples.wizard, does not match outer scope rule:
L/org.eclipse.examples.wizard/Sample File

*** Bug 63972 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Only reproducible on RC2 with the Text editor - the Java editor works fine.

Created an attachment (id=12238)
TextFileDocumentProvider.diff

Fixes the problem by specifying the "create" scheduling rule if the file to be
saved does not yet (or anymore in this case) exist. Similar code is already in
place in FileDocumentProvider.getSaveRule.

A bug I filed (Bug 63972) was marked as a dup of this one. However, I just tried
the patch and it does not fix the problem I reported. I still see:
"Unhandled event loop exception
Reason:
Attempted to beginRule: R/, does not match outer scope rule: P/Temp"

The problem is that o.e.jface.dialogs.ContainerGenerator does not construct a
proper ruler when creating the container, but always locks the entire workspace.
The ContainerGenerator in o.e.filebuffers is smarter and only gets the minimal
lock, which is included in the creationRule for the file to create.

FileDocumentProvider should also use such a ContainerGenerator.

Created an attachment (id=12255)
FileDocumentProvider.diff

Replaces org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.ContainerCreater by
org.eclipse.filebuffers.internal.ContainerCreator, which should solve your
problem.

It does not solve the problem, however, that the user can manually enter a
multi-segment path.
The patch from comment #8 did the trick (for Bug 63972). Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=12269)
org.eclipse.ui.editors.diff

Alternative patches, that also allows arbitrary folder structures to be
created.

Created an attachment (id=12271)
ContainerGenerator.diff

together with attachment 12269

Created an attachment (id=12272)
CompilationUnitDocumentProvider.diff

together with attachment 12269

Created an attachment (id=12371)
org.eclipse.ui.editors.diff

This is the better way to do this - ContainerGenerator should really also query
an IResourceRuleFactory instead of doing its own magic (bug 67604). The rule is
now computed in TextFileDocumentProvider (or the legacy FileDocumentProvider,
respectively). 

Note that if bug 67601 is fixed, the computation may not be needed any longer.

Created an attachment (id=12372)
CompilationUnitDocumentProvider.diff

together with attachment 12371
approved by Kai. fixed for I200406171600
Verified Bug 63972 (dup of this one) with Build id: 200406180010.
